newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Australian debt simmers down,confident of rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Australian debt simmers down,confident of rate cut.

text.p: *Australian debt simmered down after Thursday's blistering rally, but although the RBA remained silent on policy, analysts feel that an easing is on cards.
*Housing finance weaker than expected at down 8.4 percent.

The Australian debt market simmered down after Thursday's blistering rally which took long dated yields to their lowest level in 3-1/2 years, but remained convinced that monetary policy would be loosened again.

The Reserve Bank remained silent on policy after Thursday's weaker than expected employment report, although this came as no great surprise given that it may have been seen as a panic reaction to a lagging indicator, analysts said.
They saw such a move as more likely after the inflation and wages reports later this month and possibly after the August 5 board meeting.

"For bonds, it is consoldiation time. The three-year part of the curve now looks to be close to fully priced...and the 10-year bonds need an injection of fresh news to spike towards 6.5 percent and 25 basis points on the spread to the U.S.," said economists at Citibank Australia in a report.
The Australian/U.S. 10-year bond yield spread sank to around 35 basis points at one stage on Thursday, its lowest level since the early 1980s.
A larger than expected 8.4 percent fall in May housing finance drew little reaction from the market, being largely a correction to the 12.2 percent jump the previous month.

The local market slightly underperformed the U.S. and Canada after Thursday's sharp tightening. However, it narrowed to the short-end of the New Zealand curve following a larger than expected March quarter current account and after the RBNZ warned that monetary conditions were too easy.
